content:
Let AAA be a strict nnn-category, and let B=A⨿∂GnGnB = A \amalg_{\partial \mathbb G_n} \mathbb G_nB=A⨿∂Gn​​Gn​ be the result of gluing a copy of the nnn-globe Gn\mathbb G_nGn​ onto AAA via some "attaching map" ϕ:∂Gn→A\phi : \partial \mathbb G_n \to Aϕ:∂Gn​→A. Let ν\nuν denote the "new" nnn-globe of BBB (i.e. the one we freely glued on). For 0≤k≤n−10 \leq k \leq n-10≤k≤n−1, let ∘k\circ_k∘k​ denote kkk-composition in BBB -- i.e. it's the composition operation which requires the appropriate kkk-dimensional boundaries to agree.

I'm interested in studying certain "presentations" of nnn-morphisms in BBB, which for the moment I'll call "doohickeys", defined inductively as follows. First, ν\nuν is "presented "by a unique doohickey of "order" −1-1−1. Inductively, if ggg is presented by a doohickey of "order" k−1k-1k−1, then the composite globe a+(k)∘kg∘ka−(k)a_+^{(k)} \circ_{k} g \circ_{k} a_-^{(k)}a+(k)​∘k​g∘k​a−(k)​ is presented by a doohickey of "order" kkk whenever a−(n),a+(k)∈Ana_-^{(n)},a_+^{(k)} \in A_na−(n)​,a+(k)​∈An​ are nnn-cells such that this composite is defined.

So a doohickey is an nnn-morphism of BBB equipped with a choice of a way to present it in a particular way as a composite of ν\nuν with nnn-morphisms (a−(0),a+(0),…,a−(n−1),a+(n−1))(a_-^{(0)},a_+^{(0)}, \dots , a_-^{(n-1)},a_+^{(n-1)})(a−(0)​,a+(0)​,…,a−(n−1)​,a+(n−1)​) of AAA. The question is

What should "doohickeys" actually be called? And what should the "order" of a doohickey be called? And is there a better term than "presentation" for what I'm describing above?

Some notes:

  1. In the cases I'm interested in, every nnn-morphism of BBB which is not in AAA is presentable by a doohickey, but this is not true in general. For instance, if ν\nuν is composable with itself, then the composite ν∘iν\nu \circ_i \nuν∘i​ν is not presentable by a doohickey.

  2. Makkai called something very similar a "pre-atom". The difference is that Makkai studies a situation where one is gluing on many nnn-morphisms at once, and he reserves "pre-atom" for the case where a−,a+a_-,a_+a−​,a+​ are less than nnn-dimensional. This is because he will then build up "molecules" from the "atoms" presented by his "pre-atoms". I'm not wild about this terminology because I like my "atoms" to be _indecomposable_, whereas the globes presented by doohickeys are very much decomposable.

1. Makkai's terminology has some nice things going for it, though. For instance, you might extend the physics analogy by calling (as Makkai does) ν\nuν the "nucleus" of the atom. You might also think of the morphisms aϵka_\epsilon^kaϵk​ which go into a "doohickey" as being at different "energy levels" for different values of kkk (I think probably higher kkk would correspond to a higher energy level than lower kkk).

1. I've experimented "pre-cell", which is decent. I've also thought about using "peapod" because that's what my drawing of a doohickey looks like in dimension n=2n=2n=2 -- but that analogy doesn't seem to go too far. I don't know if there's some kind of cell biology analogy to be made.

1. The thing that I'm doing with doohickeys is to describe (under restrictive hypotheses) the precise equivalence relation on doohickeys which you need to quotient by to get the set of nnn-morphisms of BBB which are not in AAA. The equivalence relation as I've written it seems pretty suggestive: it's the reflexive symmetric transitive closure of what you get when you allow one of the aϵ(k)a_\epsilon^{(k)}aϵ(k)​'s to be "absorbed" (via an appropriate pasting) into aδ(k+1)a_\delta^{(k+1)}aδ(k+1)​ -- somehow like an atom passing to an "excited state" or something.

1. I think the main thing which is awkward about adopting Makkai's terminology to this situation is that the place where the "atomic physics analogy" lives (cf. (5) above) is at the level of doohickeys. So I'd want to call a doohickey an "atom" rather than a "pre-atom". But then it feels kind of awkward that "the thing presented by a doohickey/atom" is a "cell/globe/nnn-morphism", none of which are terms which naturally sound like "a thing presented by an atom". (That plus (as mentioned in (2) above) the unfortunate point about "atoms" being decomposable... but I suppose this is unavoidable if one really wants to use an atomic physics analogy.)

1. In the atomic orbital analogy, the number kkk which I called the "order" might be thought of as being like the principal quantum number, which fits well with the idea of "energy levels". It's then a bit unfortunate that the next quantum number -- the azimuth is, in actual physics, a number in a restricted interval rather than {−,+}\{-,+\}{−,+}-valued. And the quantum numbers which are {−,+}\{-,+\}{−,+}-valued, like spin, don't really have names which fit very well here.

  2. Maybe I could think of nnn as the "principal quantum number" nnn, the "order" kkk as the "azimuth" ℓ\ellℓ, and then regard each cell aiϵa_i^\epsilonaiϵ​ as being located at an "angle", because the next atomic number mmm is associated to angular momentum. This almost works out perfectly -- in atomic physics, mmm is an integer between −ℓ-\ell−ℓ and ℓ\ellℓ. I think this actually works out for me if I shift my indexing by 111, to think of ν\nuν itself as being associated to "angle number" m=0m=0m=0; then forming a+(k)∘kg∘ka−(k)a_+^{(k)}\circ_k g \circ_k a_-^{(k)}a+(k)​∘k​g∘k​a−(k)​ from ggg is like providing angular momentum data at m=k+1m=k+1m=k+1, both for −(k+1)-(k+1)−(k+1) and +(k+1)+(k+1)+(k+1)...

(8) is a tortured analogy for sure, even though it works hilariously well! Maybe it would be distracting to fit the terminology to it...

I've lost you a bit on the last part but I can tell some things:

  • I would not suggest going for atom and molecule because that's also the terminology that Steiner used in the 90s and that I recuperated for certain combinatorial encodings of shapes of pasting diagrams. (It is also exactly correct that in this case the "atoms" are indecomposable, so it seems like a better usage).

• So if I understand correctly your "doohickeys" are particularly shaped diagram in BBB, where the "outer part" actually has image in AAA. In one preprint, I considered a similar diagram shape, which is different only in that the aα(k)a_\alpha^{(k)}aα(k)​ are supposed to be kkk-dimensional cells; with this provision, if ν\nuν is nnn-dimensional, I called one of your "order nnn doohickeys" a shell for ν\nuν.
That preprint got superseded by one in which I did not use the “shell” construction, so as far as I'm concerned you are free to pick up the name if you like it.
• The “order” of a doohickey is exactly what Steiner calls the frame dimension of its shape as a pasting diagram.
(That includes the fact that the frame dimension of the “atom” ν\nuν is -1!)
So my naming suggestion would be to say something like “A shell of order kkk for ν\nuν in AAA”. You can even still keep your orbital analogies since electron shell is used in physics.
(Or “a shell of order kkk around ν\nuν”, if you want.)

Amar Hadzihasanovic said:

  • So if I understand correctly your "doohickeys" are particularly shaped diagram in BBB, where the "outer part" actually has image in AAA. In one preprint, I considered a similar diagram shape, which is different only in that the aα(k)a_\alpha^{(k)}aα(k)​ are supposed to be kkk-dimensional cells; with this provision, if ν\nuν is nnn-dimensional, I called one of your "order nnn doohickeys" a shell for ν\nuν.

Thanks, I do like the term "shell"!

The dimensionality restriction you have on your "shells" (the condition that aα(k)a_\alpha^{(k)}aα(k)​ be kkk-dimensional) is, I think, the same dimensionality restriction which Makkai puts on on his "pre-atoms" (I presume you're using the same indexing as Makkai, which is off by one from the indexing I've been using) . So I guess the difference is that your "shells" are a bit closer to doohickeys in that you're allowing for the case where AAA already has some nnn-dimensional cells, which can appear in the top position (as aα(n)a_\alpha^{(n)}aα(n)​ in Makkai's indexing, or aα(n−1)a_\alpha^{(n-1)}aα(n−1)​ in my indexing)?

I'm not including this dimensionality restriction in the definition of a doohickey. This doesn't allow me to represent more cells, but rather just gives me a bit more flexibility in how to represent them and describe the equivalence relation on them by which one quotients to get the cells of BBB. I should think a bit about how essential this flexibility is to my approach...
@Amar Hadzihasanovic Given a shell σ\sigmaσ around ν\nuν, do you have a name for "the morphism of AAA appearing as aϵ(k)a^{(k)}_\epsilonaϵ(k)​ in σ\sigmaσ"?

Or, given a∈Aa \in Aa∈A, do you have a name for "the (k,ϵ)(k,\epsilon)(k,ϵ) such that there exists a shell σ\sigmaσ around ν\nuν where a=aϵ(k)a = a_\epsilon^{(k)}a=aϵ(k)​ in σ\sigmaσ"? (this may not be unique in general, but I'm generally making assumptions which implies that it is unique if it exists).
Oh, I got the indexing wrong in my reply, in fact I would use the same as you and have the aα(k)a_\alpha^{(k)}aα(k)​ be (k+1)(k+1)(k+1)-dimensional.
But no, I don't have any name for the individual parts of the shell, as far as I'm concerned you're free to pursue the “quantum number” story ;)
(And yes, I do allow for the case that there are already some nnn-dimensional cells around)
